Thank you for your support. We are going to fight until the end, but if we do not win, Mindy Finn (my running mate) and my team believe that it's time for a new conservative movement that is dedicated to the equality and personal liberty of all Americans. We're already building that and what comes next isn't yet clear (perhaps a new party). I support state rights. So if a state wants to legalize marijuana, it should have the right to do that. For the record, I don't think that's a particularly wise course of action and if my state were ever voting on that, I would vote against legalization. All that said, I support the states' right to decide.
The Winking Skeever's got warm beds and cold mead. You look like you could use both.

Perfectly within your rights to hold such an opinion, but just FYI, as an independent voter (and Mormon, FWIW) , this doesn't seem like a conservative position to me, but a nakedly partisan and barely defensible one.  It is certainly not a position that conserves the tradition or likely intent of the constitution. 

If you feel the Senate should have rejected Garland as not sufficiently originalist, that's one thing. And I suppose opposition to a once Hatch-favored nominee is consistent with your speculated future bid for Hatch's seat. 

 But if you're on board with this new pulled-out-of-someone's-butt "norm" where the entire last year of an opposition presidency is somehow lame-duck territory, as far as I'm concerned, you forfeit the right to present yourself as some kind of antidote to what the political process is currently offering.  

Trump didn't happen in a vacuum. He's a natural outgrowth of a lot of stuff that the Republican party has been sowing for decades, and that's directly tied up with the recent refusal to have confirmation hearings and votes. Your strategic candidacy indicates you are (or someone associated with your campaign is) smart enough to know this. Do you want to just take advantage of yawning chasm that's opening up as a result? Or are you principled enough to offer people more than your own opportunity as an alternative?
Don't think you'll get special treatment just because you have a house in the city...

To the people saying the psychologist was incompetent, that is unfair to both the patient and the psychologist.  We know nothing about the veracity of the information being presented and we don't know the state of affairs of the communications in the office.

If the patient was "fired" it took a long time to happen and the psychologist may have tried everything they could.  In the end they could have kept seeing them and billing, or forced the patient to get a new view which may help.

The sheer fact of the matter is that if the patient doesn't actually want help, and the support structure isn't there around them (parents, friends, school, et. al) no amount of help is going to help.  

To the OP, if this is real, the way you have answered other questions makes it sound like this is a joke, either to your inner self or just in general. 

If this is real, you need to find a different group of people to be with.   Ones which will not accept your issues as something OK, but who will support and help you to change (this is the only reason AA works for some people). This process is not going to be easy, but like drug abuse and many other things it is best to cut the behavior and the bad support structure cold turkey and move on.

Take a look at what is going on and think about your affect on your own life and those around you, figure out how you want to create a positive influence and then WRITE DOWN a plan to get there.  Share it with your support structure and live by it.

Good luck!

BTW: you would have friends if you told them.  That's an insecure 16 year old's thought process.  I know it seems incredibly difficult and scary, but that just isn't how any of this works.  Admit you need help to people you trust and its pretty amazing what can happen.

This country will work best with two robust parties who can have passionate but respectful disagreements about policies and ideals instead of the demagoguery that we're witnessing.

I got started for the worst and most naive reason possible: I was bored and thought that porn would be a fun way to make some extra spending money. It spiraled out of control and eventually became a full-time job, until I decided to quit and regain some normalcy in my life. 

I didn't know anyone in the industry starting out, so I made amateur films with local college girls who I recurited at bars and frat parties. (I was, at the time, a senior in college myself.)

I had a website (now defunct) where I published this content, and when I had accumulated enough videos, I submitted my work to a European porn producer via cold-call email. He saw potential and agreed to take me on as a director/producer at his company. I spent two years there, gradually taking on more responsibility until I eventually became the de-facto studio boss. My *actual* boss controlled the finances, but I did everything else. He spent most of his time drinking and trying to bang the models.

It's a complicated crisis of course, but we must start by recognizing that Bashar al-Assad's industrial scale slaughter of Syrian civilians has created the environment in which ISIS is thriving in Syria and it has been the core cause of the refugee crisis as well. In response, I think we should work with the international community to support friendly regional forces on the ground, create safe zones in the north and south, and in doing so, weaken Assad on the battlefield. THEN, we should use that leverage to negotiate his departure from Syria. I also think we should paint the entire country with full-spectrum radar so that we can see exactly where and when Assad and the Russians are dropping bombs on civilians. Then I think we should publish that information for the world to see.

My next question would be this: as much as I would personally love for you to win the election, if it should not happen, what would your political plans be going forward the next few years? Would you plan on running again in 2020? I think given the state of the GOP you would be seen as an immediate leading candidate.

Edit: Oh, I did have one more question. Why do you think people aren't focusing as much on your religion as they were on Romney when he ran?
